Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on rock surface showing finely pecked figures of two humans, eleven cattle, five giraffes, five dogs, two antelope, five unidentified animals and three unidentified shapes. All figures are upright. Top (left to right): Unidentified shape; outline of cow facing right; giraffe facing right; human figure face on with unidentified shapes in hands (shield? Spear?); cow with two naturalistic coat pattern markings lacking infill, another, similar, above it. Centre (left to right): scimitar-horned oryx facing right, cut off edge of rock; giraffe facing left; below this cow facing left with c-curved horns intersecting infilled giraffe facing right; two unidentified shapes; below them cow facing right with grid-style coat pattern markings and wide horns; another with two naturalistic coat pattern markings lacking infill and another with grid-style coat pattern markings; another, cut off edge of image at neck. Bottom (left to right): scimitar-horned oryx surrounded by five attacking dogs; cow and infilled giraffe intersecting mentioned above; two unidentified quadrupeds; giraffe facing left; outline of cow at bottom right of image facing right. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
